Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 153.55, down 18.5 (-10.75%), High: 166.85, Low: 152.80, Volume: 68.73m

11:09 am
BE

I'm baffled why the divi cut wasn't already in the price. I mean, we're in year eight of nil interest rates with no end in sight.

BE

Barclays CET1's only 11%. It can't collect deposits because it can't make a turn on them. Its IB is crap.

BE

(Sorry, Barclays IB. I'll try and phrase that more politely for the paper copy.)

11:11 am
BE

How can a bank in these conditions return capital?

BE

Incidentally, I continue to be of the view that Lloyds' special divi will go down in history as the dumbest move of the current banking crisis.

PM

hahaha

11:11 am
PM

Yes!

BE

(Which isn't really a crisis, of course. Just a slow grind into structural unprofitability.)

BE

Anyway, let's get RBC to to sum op the various moving parts here.

11:13 am
BE

The focus is expected to be on rising capital requirements and the impact on EPS from the divestment of Africa as well as the dividend being rebased. Latest
reported TBV is 275p and Barclays is trading on 0.63x so the long term ROTE priced in is relatively low but it will take time to gain credit for the plan. Our rating
is Sector Perform.
Q4 15 results below expectations
Q4 15 adjusted pre-tax ex CTA of £501m vs consensus of £809m. The results were weaker than expected in Non Core especially with an adjusted pre-tax loss
ex CTA of £555m vs £361m loss in consensus due to negative revenues including losses on ESHLA portfolio (£156m negative). The Core adj. pre-tax ex CTA
was 10% below expectations at £1,056m partly due to the corporate centre but the other divisions were also slightly weaker. The IB made an underlying pre-tax
loss of £69m in Q4. IB revenue was flat for the full year as previously indicated (down -12% YoY in Q4 15).
CET1 better in Q4 15
11.4% reported vs 11% consensus but comment will go down in Q1 16 due to seasonality although expect it to improve over the course of 2016. The Q4 15
CET1 was better in spite of high charges - £1.45bn on PPI as lower RWAs in both core and Non Core – so that RWAs fell by 6% in Q4. The TBV fell 5% to
275p in the quarter.

BE

Dividend cut 2016/2017
While Barclays announced a 3.5p final dividend for 2015, so a flat full year 6.5p dividend, it has announced a dividend of 3p a year for 2016 and 2017. This will
save about £1.2bn or 30bp of CET1.
Higher capital ratio targets
Barclays Pillar 2A has risen from 1.6% to 2.2%. It puts its total capital ratio requirement at 11.7% Jan 2019 including a CCB and with a 100-150bp buffer
means a 12.7-13.2% vs previous target of above 12% by Jan 2019.
Africa stake sale
Announced proposed sell down of 62.3% stake in Barclays Africa Group over 2-3 years. This along with DPS cut is expected to add at least 100bp to CET1.
Oil
If oil stays at $30 expect £250m of loan losses in 2016, and if falls to $25 £450m of loan losses. Total exposure of £18.2bn of which £4.4bn on balance sheet.
Barclays took £106m of oil provisions in 2015.
Non Core
Adding an additional £8bn of RWAs to non core (£55bn pro forma for this) and keeping the £20bn target for RWAs by end 2017 unchanged. Pointing to negative
revenues of -£200m to -£800m depending on ESHLA. Also £400m of restructuring costs.
Outlook
Comments on revenues in the IB so far as being flat YTD, which is encouraging but points to a strong March 15 so expect to be down YoY in Q1 '16. Also
pointing to worsening negative income from ESHLA in Q1 '16 due to wider gilt swap spreads.

BE

Those are the bullet points.

11:13 am
PM

How are they actually going to sell down this Barc Africa stake?

PM

In JoBurg placings?

BE

I'd slightly ignored the Africa angle. Lots of reports over the weekend of an exit rather than a selldown.

11:14 am
PM

This was one of Barc's four strategic pillars up until recently

PM

Exiting Africa to bolster its capital ratios, which are rubbish cos it's paying a dividend, which will now be cut

PM

The strategy kinda seems upside down

11:16 am
BE

I'm thinking we should keep a record of the number of times banks get kitchen sinked.

BE

One could argue that this is Barclays being kitchen sinked for about the seventh time, and it's shortly before a new CEO arrives to kitchen sink it again.

BE

Jefferies incoming.

11:17 am
BE

Capital was the big story for BARC in Q4 15 across several dimensions: 1) Non-
Core: We were positively surprised at RWA reduction in the Non-Core, where levels fell to
£47bn in Q4, from £55bn at Q3, with a particularly encouraging £6bn reduction in the
derivatives bucket - where acceleration should continue given the recently announced deal
to novate client positions to JPM - all of this enabled a 40bps CET1 ratio surprise to 11.4%;
2) Dividend: company declared 6.5p of DPS for FY 15 and is cutting this to 3p, paid semiannually - we had been arguing for a cut; 3) Africa: company announced intent to sell
down its stake in Barclays Africa to deconsolidate for accounting and regulatory purposes;
4) Leverage exposure reduction ongoing: down 10% QoQ and 17% YoY, and enabling an
increase in the leverage ratio to 4.5% from 4.2% at Q3. Barclays' actions on the dividend and Africa should add 100bps of CET1 to ongoing capital generation. This gives us confidence that the company can meet at least a 13.5% CET1 ratio by end 2017.

BE

FY results a miss split equally across core/non-core: Q4 revenues were 6% soft, with
impairments £151m higher on the back of asset growth and model changes in card and PPI
charges £450m higher. Core investment banking revenues - which had already been guided to flat for FY 15 - showed a very poor performance in equities in our view (down 26% QoQ and 24% YoY) and the overall outlook for Q1 is that trading is likely to be sub-par. Despite the various misses (Africa trading was also poor), Core EPS = 25.7p for FY 15 was up 1.7p for the year and represents a 9.3% return on group tangible equity. We do not believe our
2017 core EPS estimate of 30p is a stretch.

BE

Modest restructuring, not reinventing the wheel. Barclays intends to focus on the
UK ring-fenced bank (scale consumer and business banking: £75bn of RWAs) and Corporate businesses (wholesale & consumer outside of the ring fence = £195bn RWAs) after running down its stake in Africa and adding an incremental £8bn of RWAs to the non-core (though still maintaining non-core RWA guidance of £20bn for 2017).

11:19 am
BE

And Shore.

BE

Barclays has published a pretty dismal set of full year results to 31st December 2015 with adjusted pre-tax profit of £5.4bn (Shore: £5.5bn; consensus: £5.8bn) falling short of our own and company-collated consensus expectations primarily due to weaker than anticipated income performance. In addition, the group took another £2.1bn of below-the-line charges in Q4 including £1.45bn for UK customer redress (PPI etc) which resulted in a statutory pre-tax profit of £2.1bn (Shore: £2.3bn) and a Q4 loss of £1.9bn.

While profitability disappointed, capital ratios came in ahead of expectations with a period core tier 1 ratio of 11.4% (Shore: 11.1%) and leverage ratio of 4.5% (Shore: 4.1%). However, TNAV per share was 15p weaker than we forecast at 275p (Shore: 290p). The dividend per share was held at 6.5p (Shore: 6.5p), as previously guided by management, but management has announced that it plans to cut the full year dividend to 3p per share in 2016F and 2017F in order to conserve capital.

Management has also announced a package of strategic measures to improve performance:

In addition to revising guidance on the dividend, management has also confirmed that it plans to exit its African operations (BAGL*) over the course of the next two years which, combined with the dividend cut, is expected to add around 1.0ppts to the core tier 1 ratio, with management targeting operating with a ratio 1.0-1.5ppts above the regulatory minimum in due course. We note that the minimum requirement appears to have increased by 1.1ppts to 11.7% (from 10.6% previously), implying a new minimum core tier 1 ratio requirement of 12.7%-13.2%. This is much more in line with the 13% minimum that peers are targeting.

Management has also announced that a further £8bn of RWAs will be transferred into non-core in, what it describes as, a ‘one time expansion’ …. hmmm. That said, management is still guiding that it can reduce non-core RWAs down to £20bn by the end of 2017, which is unchanged.

Management has set a new target of reducing new core bank costs to £12.8bn (ex BAGL) for 2016F versus £14.5bn (inc BAGL) previously. Barclays African operations had total costs of £2.3bn in 2015, so it looks to us like the cost guidance is actually slightly worse on a like for like basis. We await further clarification on this. The target is for a group cost:income ratio of less than 60% in due course versus 69% (adjusted) in 2015A.

It looks also like return on equity guidance has been dropped, with management now simply expecting the core and group ROTE to coverge over time with the aim of achieving an ‘attractive return for shareholders’, but we cannot see where this has been defined.

Overall, this is a pretty disappointing update from Barclays and we suspect the market will not be too impressed by the changes to guidance or the measures being taken to improve performance. Cost cutting does not seem to be aggressive enough, to us, and the lack of formal guidance on ROTE is a little worrying. Based on the last reported TNAV per share of 275p the shares are trading on a P/TNAV of just 0.6x with a prospective dividend yield (based on 3p of DPS) of under 2%. The stock may seem optically cheap on P/TNAV metrics, but we continue to prefer the better capitalised Lloyds^ (LLOY, Buy at 72p) and RBS^ (RVS, Buy at 224p). HOLD

PM

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 130.30, down 2.95 (-2.21%), High: 137.15, Low: 124.75, Volume: 49.53m
11:22 am
PM

Ivan:

PM

"Our rigorous focus on debt reduction, supply discipline and cost efficiencies enabled Glencore to record a robust performance in difficult market conditions. Our diversified portfolio, based around a core of Tier 1 assets, combined with our highly resilient marketing business, underpins our ability to continue to be comfortably cash generative at current and even lower commodity prices."

BE

Much of the Glencore stuff is rear view mirror, of course. The big numbers with regards the bottom line aren't a surprise, though they make exciting headlines.

11:23 am

Strip all that out and you get results more or less where the consensus expected.

BE

And guidance -- once again -- that everything's on track.

11:24 am
BE

As in, Glencore found itself in a hole because of the commodity crash and is doing everything it can to dig its way out.

BE

Of course, the idea that Glencore's a blameless victim of circumstance isn't a narrative I entirely believe in, but whatever.

BE

Here's Caz to summarise where we are.

11:25 am
BE

Glencore’s FY’15 earnings are in line. Reported net debt of $25.9bn is higher
than $24.4bn JPMe, but we think the focus should be the more aggressive
guidance on debt reduction in 2016-17 than previous, which reinforces our
positive investment case. Underlying EBITDA of $8.69bn is -1% JPMe (in
line with consensus), EPS of USc10.0/sh in line with JPMe (+15% vs.
consensus). FCF of $2.17bn was weaker than JPMe in H2’15, driven by a
weaker working capital release. More significant, is YE’16 $17-18bn targeted
ND ($18-19bn previous) and $15bn at YE’17 equivalent to ~2x guided markto-
market EBITDA of $8.1bn. In addition, guided mark-to-market 2016E FCF
is now "greater than $3bn" vs. c.$2.3bn provided in Dec'15. We retain conviction on
GLEN’s attractive investment case, namely timely debt reduction will drive an
ongoing equity re-rating. Since peaking on 20th Jan at 1,165bps, the CDS has
fallen 43% and GLEN’s shares are +80%. We remain OW.

BE

Balance sheet & cash flow: GLEN’s investment case is driven by success
of its de-leveraging strategy. $25.9bn YE’15 net debt (net 100% of Readily
Marketable Inventory) was $1.5bn higher than $24.4bn JPMe. However,
YE’16E guidance of $17-18bn (JPMe $24.4bn) has been reduced by $1bn
and GLEN also introduced a YE’17E target of c.$15bn which is better than
expected (JPMe $15.6bn). Cash generation was strong – H2’15 FFO was
$3.59bn (JPMe $3.22bn); however, FCF of $2.2bn (JPMe $4.3bn) was
below JPMe driven by a weaker working capital performance, where the H2
release of $1.85bn was well below JPMe $3.70bn. FY’15 capex was
$5.96bn (JPMe $5.69bn) and 2016E Industrial capex guidance has been
reduced by $300m to $3.5bn.

BE

Update on Agriculture disposal: GLEN expects to reach agreement on the
sale of a minority stake in the Agricultural Products business in Q2’16. We
assume sale of a 25% stake in H2 for total proceeds of $2bn. Asset disposal
target increased to $4-5bn from $3-4bn previously, with additional funds
expected from precious metals and a selection of infrastructure / logistics.

11:26 am
BE

Skipping a bit with regards industrial still being lossmaking and marketing being all there is.

BE

We upgraded GLEN to OW in Dec’15, citing
exaggerated concerns for its balance sheet, and we expect its equity will rerate
as credit risk premiums recede. We highlight GLEN’s 5yr CDS peaked
at 1,165bps on 20th Jan and have since fallen to 662bps, whilst over this
period its share price is +80%. Furthermore, GLEN is attractively valued, in
our view, on mark-to market 7.1x/7.9x EV/EBITDA with a robust FCF yield
of 21.6%/9.3% in 2016/17E vs. peer average 5.4%/7.6%.

BE

This was always the point of Glencore, though, right? Its marketing business is reasonably predictable and stable even when Xstrata as was is burning money.

11:28 am
undefined
PM

Can we return to Barclays just briefly

BE

Again? Sure.

11:29 am
PM

Someone's sent me Barc note from 2010

PM

BE

11:29 am
PM

357p -- sell

PM

Only seller at the time, it seems

PM

7 years of famine?
If it were possible for a bank to have a “good” credit crisis, then
Barclays might be said to have had one. Over the last 7 years,
the Group has grown top line income by 18% CAGR to £35bn,
while avoiding many of the toxic assets and poorly timed
acquisitions that have brought down rivals. If we extrapolate a
further 7 years of abundance, Barclays Capital top line will be
33 times the revenue of the UK Retail Bank.
Absurd? We think so too.

11:30 am
PM

We rate Barclays a SELL, TP 276p
We like many aspects of the bank and management, but believe it is not a “buy and
hold” investment. The last 20 years have seen four episodes where the share price
declined 45% percent or more, peak to trough. Most recently, the share price fell
90% peak to trough over the last 2 years. Share price declines of this frequency and
magnitude do not make sense for a company with a conservative capital structure
and stable revenues.
Understandably, Barclays is reducing balance sheet leverage but we are deeply
sceptical of the idea that any bank can achieve 15-20% Return on Equity regardless
of the amount of equity or total assets.
Barclays management is diligent, hard working and even talented. Up until the first
half of 2007, we believe all banks benefited from demographic trends, which have
generated global GDP growth, for which the role of an Iowa farm lad called Norman
Borlaug should be more widely acknowledged.

PM

His target price was a tad optimistic

PM

We should do more of this -- pulling out old notes

BE

FTSE 250 constituents that are eligible for potential demotion into the FTSE Small Cap Index are as follows:

· Enterprise Inns

888 Holdings is currently eligible to be removed from the FTSE 250, as it does not meet Rule 4.4.3 of the FTSE UK Index Series Ground Rules. The rule states that if a company is not incorporated in the UK, it must meet a number of requirements including a free float greater than 50%.

For the purposes of balancing the potential entry of four constituents in the FTSE 250, two constituents nearest to the 376th threshold will need to potentially move into the FTSE Small Cap Index. As at Monday 29 February this constituent would be Nostrum Oil & Gas and Melrose Industries.

Ashtead Group PLC (AHT:LSE): Last: 800.00, down 124 (-13.42%), High: 885.00, Low: 753.50, Volume: 5.71m
BE

Yeah, priced for growth that now looks a bit more uncertain than it did yesterday.

11:38 am
BE

You'll remember Ashtead's outperformed United Rentals, its main peer, on the idea that it was taking market share.

BE

So we've got a bit of a reset heading into 2017.

BE

Here's Barclays.

11:39 am
BE

Ashtead has delivered 3Q16 adjusted PBT of £139m, +17% yoy at CER. As in previous
quarters, the solid growth is a result of a combination of rental revenue growth (+14%)
and margin progression (EBITDA margin +140bps). At 14%, Sunbelt’s 3Q rental
revenue growth has slowed vs. the 19% delivered in 2Q16, although we note that 3Q is
the toughest yoy quarterly comp during FY16, so this slowing is not entirely
unexpected. While Ashtead management continues to see “strong end markets”, they
are also not blind to the current debate around the outlook for the US economy and this
is reflected in a sensible approach to FY17 capex planning, giving a broad initial range
of £0.7-1.0bn. Adopting a similarly conservative approach, we have reset our forecasts
at the lower end of this capex guidance, and lowered our yield assumptions, which
results in a reduction to our FY17F PBT of 6%, still equating to yoy profit growth of 11%
vs. FY16F. With Ashtead entering a phase of the cycle where both replacement and
growth capex requirements are reducing, we expect double-digit profit growth to be
accompanied by improved cash generation and leverage reducing. Our base case
remains that the US is slowing, not entering a recession, and we continue to believe
that in a ‘grind-upwards’ recovery in US non-resi, market conditions are favourable for
the rental industry, and Ashtead in particular given its strong track record for
outperforming the industry. We reduce our PT to 1135p (from 1434p) reflecting our
lower forecasts, and a lower multiple given the more uncertain US outlook.

BE

Maintenance capex requirements drop significantly in FY17: Ashtead is now entering
the replacement phase for equipment purchased in FY09-11, when capex was
extremely low – this coupled with moderating growth demands should see Ashtead’s
free cash flow improve significantly, and leverage reduce, over the next few years - we
forecast net debt/EBITDA of 1.5x at 30-Apr-17F, falling to 1.1x 30-Apr-18F.

BE

CY2016 EV/EBITDA 5.3x, falling to 4.6x in CY2017. This compares to URI at 4.5x and
4.3x respectively. We believe that Ashtead merits a premium to its closest peer given its
superior growth rates. We value Ashtead’s US business at 6x EV/EBITDA and its UK
business at 5x – multiples we believe are appropriate at this stage of the cycle.

11:40 am
BE

Barclays, also, is first to write up the conference call.

BE

Key messages from the call: (1) Current trading strong: usual seasonal pick-up Jan/Feb and positive indicators for spring/summer. First month of 4Q (Feb) rental rev +19-20%, and management think 1Q17 will see growth in mid- to high-teens – reinforcing that 3Q a particularly tough comp; (2) Capex flexibility: planning to land a good level of capex in 1H given current lead indicators with flex around 2H – have 60-day lead times so no need to decide now what will be spent in FY17 - can cut or increase depending on markets; (3) Capital allocation: “See no point in de-levering significantly below 1.5x” – our forecasts see leverage at 1.5x @ 30-Apr-17 which opens up possibility of share buybacks/special dividends in FY18, clearly whatever decisions are taken will depend on what the market backdrop is at that stage. (4) Acquisitions: vendor pricing expectations elevated as smaller companies are generally seeing strong current trading – not going to pay these multiples and will just continue with greenfields (planning to open similar number in FY17 as opened in FY16 and if market turned down, would just reallocate fleet from existing branches as ambition to grow footprint holds whatever the environment is). (5) Regionally, Florida, California and Atlantic Coast are strong, weaker in Texas and other oil exposed areas but still higher yoy. In summary, shares have fallen sharply today as the focus has fallen on the moderating of top-line growth expectations rather than the message of improving cash dynamics over the next few years in a low-market growth environment – as we said in our note this morning, our base case is that this is a slower phase of growth in Ashtead’s end markets rather than a recession and we therefore see a number of years of good profit growth (accompanied by improving cash flow) ahead. Post this morning’s share price fall of 15%, the shares are trading on a CY2016E EV/EBITDA of 4.8x, falling to 4.1x in CY2017E (PE 9.2x, falling to 8.1x).

BE

And that's that.

And we haven't mentioned LSE yet.

11:46 am
BE

Anyway, Citi.

BE

We have had press reports this morning (Bloomberg, etc.) concerning the two things that DB1 likely did not wish to see. Firstly, we note reports that the CME is going to look to challenge the proposed merger between the LSE and DB1. Secondly, ICE is said to be evaluating a counterbid for the LSE, most likely sometime in late March.

Neither comes as a huge surprise, however. The LSE is an asset that has received rival bids before and, despite the Brexit risk, it is a sought after asset. This morning's news gives credence to the performance of the LSE shares in recent days, as they had begun to trade above the implied level of the agreement, after adjusting for dividends.

We do not believe that DB1 wants to find itself in a bidding war with a rival exchange (again), let alone ICE or even CME. Its balance sheet is stretched already, judged on a gross debt to EBITDA basis as per its ratings agencies, and a revision to its offer would see either a higher proportion of the combined entity go to LSE shareholders, or it would involve an equity raise, we think.

The risk in this situation is that a re-run of 2005 becomes a real danger, when the attempted take-over of the LSE by DB1 turned hostile after interest from OMX, the Swedish exchange, set the deal of course.

BE

Everyone else is restricted. There's been an unseemly rush among the IBs get onto the various tickets here.

BE

SOLO OIL+ (SOLO, 0.39p, House Stock) – Horse Hill flow testing update. Solo has announced that it has been informed by the operator that good quality oil has flowed naturally to surface from the Upper Kimmeridge limestone interval in the Horse Hill-1 well at a stabilised rate exceeding 900bopd. Flow of dry oil commenced with a rod pump yesterday at an initial instantaneous rate exceeding 700bopd; the well subsequently flowed naturally, flowing at a stabilised rate of over 900bopd. The pump rods have now been removed and the well has been reopened, enabling the recommencement of natural flow to obtain further stabilised flow and reservoir engineering data. As previously announced, on completion of testing of the Upper Kimmeridge zone, operations will move to the shallower Portland sandstone reservoir. In the meantime, we believe that today's news represents an outstanding result from the Horse Hill-1 well, where two zones have been tested independently at high natural flow rates. The test results to date have been all the more impressive because they have been achieved from a vertical well without significant stimulation; commercial production will now be a clear objective for the partners.
